Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Anionic Multitopic N-Heterocyclic Carbenes: Building Blocks for Molecular and Supramolecular Architectures
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis program of the Chemistry Division supports Professor Daniela Tapu from Kennesaw State University to investigate the synthesis and characterization of a series of rigid ligands that are designed to support multimetallic complexes and supramolecular cages. This project challenges conventional models of chemical bonding and structure. Understanding the relationship between molecular architecture, electronic structure and chemical reactivity of these new compounds may allow the development of more efficient homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts, and may lead to strategies to facilitate their recovery. This research has the potential to positively impact both the catalysis industry and academic research. Broader impacts include the training and mentoring of undergraduate and M.S. students including students from lower income families and groups traditionally underrepresented in the STEM disciplines.

This project targets a pallet of novel rigid anionic multitopic non-chelating N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) that can be applied in coordination chemistry and catalysis. These carbenes function as building blocks for a series of zwitterionic bi- and tri-metallic complexes, as well as metallosupramolecular systems, novel architectures that are not accessible with the current NHC ligands. Central to these tasks are the development of new synthetic methodologies and strategies to facilitate the synthesis of the target molecules and the evaluation of their catalytic properties. The proposed work will provide broad-based student training from developing synthetic methods to access the targeted carbenes and their complexes to characterizing their physical and electronic structures, to studying their reactivities.

Institution.Name: Kennesaw State University Research and Service Foundation
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: KENNESAW STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH AND SERVICE FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This integrated research and education program was designed to engage undergraduate and graduate (MS) students in hypothesis-driven research projects. The research component explored the synthesis and study of a series of rigid anionic multitopic nonchelating N-heterocyclic carbenes that were designed to support bi- and trimetallic complexes, as well as supramolecular structures.  Central to these tasks was the development of new synthetic methodologies and strategies to facilitate the synthesis of the target molecules. The educational component provided undergraduates and graduate students at Kennesaw State University (KSU) the opportunity to develop as young scientist-scholars in the classroom, laboratory and as presenters at scientific meetings.

This project was successful in the development of a pallet of novel rigid anionic multitopic nonchelating NHCs that can be applied in coordination chemistry and catalysis. The utility of these new carbenes as bridging ligands was established by their incorporation in a series of new zwitterionic bi- and trinuclear coinage metal complexes, novel architectures that were not accessible with the current arsenal of neutral NHC ligands. Some of these complexes exhibit the longest average metal-to-metal through-space distance for a Janus- or Cerberus type-carbene reported to date.  Due to their unique geometrical and electronic properties, the new bis- and trisNHCs have the potential to serve as building block for the preparation of an assortment of functional organic and metal-organic frameworks, microporous polymers, and porous organic molecular solids.   The fundamental nature of this work has provided useful information on carbene physical and electronic structure, reactivity, and synthetic methodology. The design of the project was well-adapted to answer questions of fundamental importance within the limitations imposed by teaching responsibilities and working in a predominantly undergraduate setting.

This project challenged the conventional models of chemical bonding and structure. Understanding the relationship between molecular architecture, electronic structure and chemical reactivity of these new compounds allows for the development of more efficient homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts and possible strategies to facilitate their recovery. Broader impacts of this project also include the training and mentoring of many undergraduate and graduate students in general principles of organic chemistry, organometallics, synthesis and theory. The lab selected its undergraduates from over 600 chemistry and biochemistry majors. Twenty-three undergraduates and four graduate students have been involved at different stages in this project. Seven of these students were females and five were minority students. Several undergraduate research students were drawn from the NSF-funded Scholarship Program in Science and Math, which focuses on mentoring science and math students who are from lower income families and the NSF-supported Peach State LSAMP Program. Students were able to complete their own research projects, participate in weekly group meetings and seminars, present at regional and national ACS meetings and KSU symposium of student scholars, and to publish their work as co-authors. Sixty-two conference presentations (15 at national meetings, 25 at regional meetings, and 22 local meetings), five papers (3 in print, 2 in preparation) and four Master theses have resulted from this project. The dissemination of our research results at meetings and in peer reviewed manuscripts provided the field with a more detailed description of the chemistry of anionic multitopic NHCs. This support allowed Tapu to develop her research and the infrastructure to serve the emerging MS program in critical need of cutting-edge training opportunities and research assistantship support. Funding positively impacted KSU by strengthening the research environment for students, the PI and her colleagues. Outreach efforts engaged hundreds of elementary and middle-school students who were exposed to science through various STEM activities (Halloween Chemistry Show at Simpson Middle School in Marietta, GAl, STEM night at Little River Elementary School in Woodstock, GA, St. Patrick’s Day Demos at KSU, and Atlanta Science Festival in downtown Atlanta).

 

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2019
Modified by: Daniela Tapu

The research component explored the synthesis and study of a series of rigid anionic multitopic nonchelating N-heterocyclic carbenes that were designed to support bi- and trimetallic complexes, as well as supramolecular structures. The utility of these new carbenes as bridging ligands was established by their incorporation in a series of new zwitterionic bi- and trinuclear coinage metal complexes, novel architectures that were not accessible with the current arsenal of neutral NHC ligands.
